summary: This document is a collection of internal Bureau of Prisons emails and memos concerning the incarceration, management, and death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details his arrival, housing assignments, psychological status, administrative actions following his death, and legal team communications. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons emails and memos from July-August 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details his arrival, placement on suicide watch and psychological observation, an alleged suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, and subsequent preservation requests for video footage. It also includes a lengthy internal review of suicide prevention protocols following Epstein's death. This document contains email chains from November 2019 and August 2019 among Bureau of Prisons staff at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The November emails discuss procedures for suicide watch placement and a 'reconstruction meeting' regarding an incident, while the August emails discuss placing staff on administrative leave and press strategy following Jeffrey Epstein's death. This document is a collection of email chains from August to November 2019 concerning the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death and the earlier suicide attempt in July 2019. It includes internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) discussions about placing staff on leave, drafting public statements, responding to media and legal inquiries, and detailing procedures and observations related to Epstein's incarceration and suicide watch. This document is a collection of email correspondence and memoranda from 2019 concerning the incarceration, suicide attempts, and death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes discussions about legal visits for another inmate (Tartaglione), internal BOP communications about Epstein's psychological status and cell assignments, investigations into missing video evidence from his first suicide attempt, and draft public statements regarding staff reassignments following his death. This document is a series of email correspondences from October 2019 regarding the detention and psychological observation of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a forwarded message detailing his watch status and observation periods in July 2019, and references an expert report on detention conditions.

events.title: Epstein's Arrival at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York and was initially placed in general population due to a lack of prior notification about his high-profile status.

events.title: Epstein Moved to SHU
events.description: The warden identified Epstein as high-profile and moved him to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) due to concerns for his personal safety in general population.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was moved to Psychology Observation for evaluation upon the return of Psychology Service staff. The notes specify this was NOT a suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU with Cellmate
events.description: Epstein was returned to the Special Housing Unit with a cellmate, where he remained until July 23.

events.title: Administrative Actions After Epstein's Death
events.description: The Attorney General directed the BOP to reassign the MCC warden, name an acting warden from FCI Otisville, and place two (or three in a draft) MCC staff on administrative leave pending investigations into Epstein's 'apparent suicide'.

events.title: Arranging Private Investigator Visit
events.description: Attorney Sarah Sacks corresponds with BOP staff to get clearance for private investigator Mr. O'Brien to visit Jeffrey Epstein at MCC on the following Monday and Tuesday.

events.title: Placed on Psychology Observation
events.description: Epstein was moved to Psychology Observation for evaluation by Psychology Service staff. This was not suicide watch, and he was under 24-hour observation.

events.title: Returned to SHU with Cell Mate
events.description: Epstein was returned to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a cell mate, where he remained until July 23.

events.title: Alleged Suicide Attempt
events.description: An incident described as Epstein's "first suicide attempt" occurred in the early morning hours while he was celled with Tartaglione. This triggered a preservation request for video footage from outside their cell.

events.title: Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was placed on Suicide Watch at 1:40 AM, following the alleged suicide attempt. He was later changed to Psychology Observation at 8:45 AM.

events.title: Ended Psychology Observation
events.description: Epstein's Psychology Observation status ended at 8:15 AM.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Apparent Suicide
events.description: The apparent suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at MCC New York, which triggered internal investigations and procedural reviews.

events.title: Staff Placed on Administrative Leave

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Death

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's initial placement in general population at MCC was due to the U.S. Marshals Service not indicating he was a high-profile inmate, so no prior plans were in place.
Epstein was placed on 'Psychological Observation' which was explicitly distinguished from 'Suicide Watch' in BOP communications, with system notes reflecting 'suicide watch not warranted'.

Following Epstein's death, the Attorney General directed the reassignment of the MCC warden and the placement of staff from his unit on administrative leave, showing immediate high-level administrative consequences.
Epstein's defense team was actively working to arrange visits from a private investigator in December 2019, indicating ongoing legal preparation.
Internal BOP emails show detailed procedural reviews and drafting of statements in the immediate aftermath of Epstein's death, highlighting the institutional response.

Video surveillance footage from outside cell Z06-215 (shared by Epstein and Tartaglione) for the time of Epstein's alleged first suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, was requested to be preserved but was later reported missing to the court, despite SIS (Special Investigative Services) advising it had been preserved.

Epstein's initial placement in general population upon arrival on July 6, 2019, was due to the U.S. Marshals Service (USMS) not indicating he was a high-profile inmate, and MCC staff being unaware of his arrival.

Internal BOP emails from July 28, 2019, document Epstein complaining of a numb right arm and neck, and a toilet in his cell that ran for 45 minutes, which he found so aversive he resorted to urinating in a cup.

A lengthy internal "Psychology Epstein Reconstruction Responses" memo outlines significant changes to suicide prevention protocols at MCC-NY following Epstein's death, including eliminating "Psychology Observation" status, enhancing cellmate assignment procedures, and improving logbook documentation.

The document reveals confusion and procedural failures in Epstein's initial handling and monitoring, including miscommunication about his status and the preservation of critical evidence (video footage).
Emails from November 2019 show MCC staff actively revising and coordinating suicide watch procedures, including specific guidance for Lieutenants and verification by Captains.
A 'reconstruction meeting' is referenced, for which a document needs to be signed by the Warden, indicating an ongoing review of an incident (likely Epstein's death).
In August 2019, following Epstein's death, the BOP placed two staff members from the MCC Special Housing Unit on administrative leave and considered reassigning the Warden.
A news article from August 15, 2019, reported an inmate was mistakenly released from MCC after Epstein's suicide, indicating further institutional issues.
The correspondence reveals internal concerns about linking staffing shortages and overtime to the Epstein incident, as mentioned in press reports.

Internal BOP emails from August 2019 show planning to place two staff from the MCC NY Special Housing Unit on administrative leave following Epstein's death, with consideration of also reassigning the Warden.

A BuzzFeed News reporter contacted MCC on August 12, 2019, about posts on 4chan that appeared to detail first responder medical procedures for Epstein's death before any public announcement, suggesting a possible leak.

Defense attorney A. Barket, on behalf of Jeffrey Epstein's legal team, requested in November 2019 all reports and video regarding Epstein's attempted suicide on July 22-23, 2019, and statements from inmate Mr. Tartaglione who was interviewed about the incident.
Detailed logs show Epstein was placed on a 'staff watch' and then an 'inmate companion' watch after his July 23 suicide attempt, and later on formal psychology observation from July 24-30, 2019.

Emails reveal internal BOP reviews and updated procedures for suicide watch placements, cell assignments, and staff notifications following Epstein's death, indicating scrutiny of institutional protocols.

Video surveillance footage from outside the cell shared by Jeffrey Epstein and inmate Tartaglione during Epstein's alleged first suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, was reported missing and the DVR footage was allegedly corrupted.
Following Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, the MCC warden was reassigned and three correctional personnel from his unit were placed on administrative leave pending FBI and OIG investigations.
Internal BOP memoranda show Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and placed on Psychological Observation on July 24, 2019, and was later moved to the Special Housing Unit (SHU).
A 2019 media inquiry revealed that 21 staff had been hired at MCC New York since Epstein's death and over $2.6 million was spent on infrastructure repairs since March 2019.
Correctional officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas were charged with falsifying documents in relation to the Epstein case, contributing to reported low staff morale at MCC.
Jeffrey Epstein was under psychological observation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in July 2019, with specific start and end times documented.
The AUSA from the SDNY was coordinating with the USMS regarding Epstein's placement and awaiting a medical summary from the UK.
An expert report on detention conditions was referenced, indicating scrutiny of Epstein's treatment in custody.
Epstein's inmate designation was #76318-054.
